features: THE EXCEPTIONAL GAMING PROCESSOR. 8 Cores and 16 processing threads, based on AMD "Zen 4" architecture .
5.4 GHz Max Boost, unlocked for overclocking, 80 MB cache, DDR5 support . For the state-of-the-art Socket AM5 platform, can support PCIe 5.0 on select 600 Series motherboards
AMD Wraith Prism RGB Cooler Included . Max. Operating Temperature (Tjmax) 95°C
body.description: The Exceptional Gaming Processor Leading your team to victory shouldn't cost a fortune. This processor brings exceptional value, overclocking, and includes the AMD Wraith Prism cooler with RBG LED lighting.

productInformation.name: Customer Reviews
productInformation.value: 4.7 4.7 out of 5 stars 242 ratings 4.7 out of 5 stars

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Solid performer at 65W
reviews.reviewText: After building my workstation (7950X bea$t for work needs) my wife started getting fomo, so I built a more reasonably budgeted machine for her around the 7700 (non X variant) and a Gigabyte Aorus Master as that MB has been consistently solid with mem compatibility (for me anyway).At stock power (65W) it's only a few percentage points off of the 7700X, and with a bit of curve optimization it can even hang with my workstation build at anything below fully threaded loads (i.e., rendering, sim compute, compilation, etc.).In everyday, normal computing use, it's absurdly fast and efficient. Nearly a third less power of the 7950X machine, but delivering between 60 ~ 90 percent of the performance across all of my benchmarks and tested use cases. That's crazy good for a machine that costs 1/5 the price.Unless you're chasing a handful of extra frames in games, or have very specific workloads where time = money, I can't see much justification in spending more money, to use more electricity, that generates more heat to cool, for like ~5% more performance with the X variant. This 7700 does nearly identical work much more efficiently, for less money.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Incredible performance and cost saving
reviews.reviewText: Its a good product and its almost as powerful as the 7700x. Its power consumption is also much lower and thus stays cool. Also, the included heatsink has thermal paste applied already so you don't need to purchase that seperately. Additonally, My pc only has 1 exhaust fan and no intake fans so the 7700 paired with my overclocked 1660ti stays moderately cool at all times. This is also due to my pc case the Phanteks P300a having a mesh front providing less air resistance. I believe this is the perfect CPU bundle to not have to buy other things such as the heatsink, extra fans, thermal paste while at the same time having a incredible amount of performance.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Unleash Multicore Power: AMD Ryzen™ 7 7700 Desktop Processor Review
reviews.reviewText: The AMD Ryzen™ 7 7700 8-Core, 16-Thread Unlocked Desktop Processor is a true powerhouse that redefines desktop computing. With its impressive multicore performance, this processor is a game-changer for professionals, enthusiasts, and gamers alike. Its unlocked nature allows for easy overclocking, further tapping into its potential, while the 8 cores and 16 threads ensure a seamless multitasking experience. Whether you're handling demanding applications or indulging in immersive gaming, the Ryzen™ 7 7700 delivers unmatched performance, making it an ideal choice for those seeking top-tier processing power.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing efficient CPU.
reviews.reviewText: This CPU is great. 30c under min load, 72c under full load. I am using the (probably overkill) Deepcool AK620 and Be Quiet! Pure Base 500DX! 65w is obviously not the CPU draw as, completely non-overclocked, it can run 88w of power. However 5nm process makes it very heat-efficient, so it's nevertheless an amazing efficient CPU. Has an amazing single core performance, perfect for my use case of Minecraft.

reviews.reviewerName: The Champ That Runs the CampThe Champ That Runs the Camp
reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I think I hit the silicon lottery
reviews.reviewText: Purchased this for a new (primarily) gaming rig with some productivity work.With PBO enabled I have multiple cores hitting just under 6100mhz at a max of 77°C with a NZXT 280mm AIO cooler.I'm happy.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good CPU - but lots of other tantalizing options at similar price point
reviews.reviewText: I would pick this up these days at about a $275 price point. For any more, I’d be considering a 7800x3d, a 7900, or maybe one of the upcoming APUs. Intel has good i5 and i7 options from multiple generations close to this price point as well. That being recognized, The AMD r7 7700 is a good CPU, with eight powerful cores on a single CCD, PBO capability which puts it up with the 7700x, and an included, tastefully RGB stock cooler that works fine. This is a good option for a lot of folks, but most mid to high end buyers will probably pass this in favor of other interesting options.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing processor for mini itx builds
reviews.reviewText: Was building a new pc in the Hyte Revolt 3 mini itx case. Was super uncomfortable with purchasing any Ryzen ‘X’ variant due to the temperatures reaching up to 95 degrees! So I waited for the lower TDP chips to come out and absolutely love this processor. Running with a 280 mm AIO in a small mini ITX case the temperatures under stress tests settle in at 68 degrees and only mid 50s when gaming.Highly recommend for small builds and even those looking for 95%~ of the performance of the X skus with half of the power drawALSO verify your cooler comes with AM5 compatible mounting hardware. Used a NZXT 280 AIO and had to purchase a different bracket that makes better contact with the AM5 platform processors.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2023
reviews.reviewText: It has been great in my new PC.
Me gusta mucho el poder de este procesador por el precio, son 8 núcleos qué me dan 5.2ghz y con pbo se puede sacar más aún. Solo hay que ponerle un mejor disipador.

reviews.reviewerName: Fantastic. Great WRAITH Prism cooler as well
reviews.reviewText: Arrived in perfect condition, overclocking capabilities r great, everything is superb. Cooler works fine too but for overclocking better to use liquid cooling

reviews.reviewTitle: Flott & effizient, aber leider noch relativ teuer
reviews.reviewText: Der Ryzen-7 7700 non-X hat meinen Core i7 12700K abgelöst.Zwar ist der Ryzen, laut Benchmarks, nicht schneller als der 12700K,aber der Energiekonsum (Spiele / Anwendungen) hat sich glatt halbiert,und damit auch der Aufwand für die Kühlung.Den beiliegenden Boxed-Kühler "Wraith Prism" habe ich auch ausprobiert.Dieser ist - im Vergleich zu Intels dünnen "Alu-Scheiben" - durchaus brauchbar.Der Preis von 330€ ist, meiner Meinung nach, noch 30€ zu hoch,weil es ab 345€ bereits die X-Variante und ab 399€ die X3D Variante gibt.(+) Energieeffizienz(+) guter Boxed Kühler(-) Preis
Un muy buen procesador de gran calidad y con una muy buena velocidad, suficiente para realizar cualquier tarea y jugar videojuegos a una buena tasa de refresco.

Shipping: Painless. It arrived ahead of schedule, with no damage whatsoever (other items were in the box).Performance: I've seen reviews that have the chip anywhere from ~-5% to +3% of the 7700X and, my particular chip runs at -3.3% that of a 7700X (real world testing, aggregate from LTT, J2C, PC Parts Picker and GN). That is at stock; I haven't overclocked it or changed the power limits.Contents: Besides the chip and Ryzen sticker, the non-X R7s come with an AMD cooler (in my case, a Wraith RGB). This is not going to win any performance awards but it is good enough for most daily driver tasks and non-overclocked gaming.Cost: In my case, I was able to pick this up for $435 all in - $55 less than the R7 7700X.Recommendation: This chip should be an easy choice for anyone looking to build their first AMD rig. The 7700X will offer better performance and better overclocking potential but it runs hotter than the 7700 and uses more power. What I find most people don't talk about is the hidden cost of the 7700X: since it does not come with a cooling solution, the user must provide one - and neither the Stealth nor Wraith coolers will be able to do the job adequately. This means that what was a $40 + tax price hike now becomes closer to $85 + for an air cooler or $100 + for a liquid cooler. (For a 7700X I would recommend a liquid cooler because of the higher temps.)The 7700 performs as well as a 7700X but with a lower TDP, lower power requirement, lower price tag and an included cooler. New builders and anyone looking to game while saving a dollar can't go wrong with any chip in the non-X R7 series.
